Indications and doses

Diabetes insipidus, treatment,

By subcutaneous injection or by intravenous injection or by intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    Initially 100 micrograms 3 times a day; maintenance 100–200 micrograms 3 times a day; usual dose 0.2–1.2 mg daily.
  • For adults
    Initially 60 micrograms 3 times a day, adjusted according to response; usual dose 40–240 micrograms 3 times a day.
  • For adults
    10–40 micrograms daily in 1–2 divided doses.
  • For adults
    1–4 micrograms daily.
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    Initially 10 micrograms 2–3 times a day, adjusted according to response; usual dose 30–150 micrograms daily.
  • For children 2–11 years
    Initially 50 micrograms 2–3 times a day, adjusted according to response; usual dose 100–800 micrograms daily.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 100 micrograms 2–3 times a day, adjusted according to response; usual dose 0.2–1.2 mg daily.
  • For children 2–17 years
    Initially 60 micrograms 3 times a day, adjusted according to response; usual dose 40–240 micrograms 3 times a day.
  • For children 1 month–1 year
    Initially 2.5–5 micrograms 1–2 times a day, adjusted according to response.
  • For children 2–11 years
    Initially 5–20 micrograms 1–2 times a day, adjusted according to response.
  • For children 12–17 years
    Initially 10–20 micrograms 1–2 times a day, adjusted according to response.

Primary nocturnal enuresis,

By sublingual administration

  • For adults 18–65 years
    200 micrograms once daily, only increased to 400 micrograms if lower dose not effective; withdraw for at least 1 week for reassessment after 3 months, dose to be taken at bedtime, limit fluid intake from 1 hour before to 8 hours after administration.
  • For adults 18–65 years
    120 micrograms once daily, increased if necessary to 240 micrograms once daily, dose to be taken at bedtime, limit fluid intake from 1 hour before to 8 hours after administration, dose to be increased only if lower dose not effective, reassess after 3 months by withdrawing treatment for at least 1 week.
  • For children 5–17 years
    200 micrograms once daily, only increased to 400 micrograms if lower dose not effective; withdraw for at least 1 week for reassessment after 3 months, dose to be taken at bedtime, limit fluid intake from 1 hour before to 8 hours after administration.
  • For children 5–17 years
    120 micrograms once daily, increased if necessary to 240 micrograms once daily, dose to be taken at bedtime, limit fluid intake from 1 hour before to 8 hours after administration, dose to be increased only if lower dose not effective, reassess after 3 months by withdrawing treatment for at least 1 week.

Postoperative polyuria or polydipsia,

By mouth

  • For adults
    Dose to be adjusted according to urine osmolality.

Polyuria or polydipsia after hypophysectomy,

By sublingual administration

  • For adults
    Dose to be adjusted according to urine osmolality.

Diabetes insipidus, diagnosis (water deprivation test),

By intramuscular injection or by subcutaneous injection

  • For adults
    20 micrograms, limit fluid intake to 500 mL from 1 hour before to 8 hours after administration.
  • For adults
    2 micrograms for 1 dose, limit fluid intake to 500 mL from 1 hour before to 8 hours after administration.

Nocturia associated with multiple sclerosis (when other treatments have failed),

By intranasal administration

  • For adults 18–65 years
    10–20 micrograms once daily, to be taken at bedtime, dose not to be repeated within 24 hours, limit fluid intake from 1 hour before to 8 hours after administration.

Renal function testing,

By subcutaneous injection or by intramuscular injection

  • For adults
    40 micrograms, empty bladder at time of administration and limit fluid intake to 500 mL from 1 hour before until 8 hours after administration to avoid fluid overload.
  • For adults
    2 micrograms, empty bladder at time of administration and restrict fluid intake to 500 mL from 1 hour before until 8 hours after administration to avoid fluid overload.

Mild to moderate haemophilia and von Willebrand’s disease,

By intravenous infusion or by subcutaneous injection

  • For adults
    300 micrograms every 12 hours if required, one 150 microgram spray into each nostril, 30 minutes before surgery or when bleeding, dose may alternatively be repeated at intervals of at least 3 days, if self-administered.
  • For adults
    300 nanograms/kg for 1 dose, to be administered immediately before surgery or after trauma; may be repeated at intervals of 12 hours if no tachycardia.

Fibrinolytic response testing,

By subcutaneous injection or by intravenous injection

  • For adults
    300 micrograms, blood to be sampled after 1 hour for fibrinolytic activity, one 150 microgram spray to be administered into each nostril.
  • For adults
    300 nanograms/kg for 1 dose, blood to be sampled after 20 minutes for fibrinolytic activity.

Lumbar-puncture-associated headache,

By intramuscular injection or by subcutaneous injection

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).

Drug action

Desmopressin is an analogue of vasopressin.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Small oxytocic effect in third trimester; increased risk of pre-eclampsia.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Use with caution; antidiuretic effect may be reduced.

Contra indications

  • Cardiac insufficiency
  • conditions treated with diuretics
  • polydipsia in alcohol dependence
  • psychogenic polydipsia

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Allergic reactions, emotional disturbance in children, epistaxis, fluid retention, headache, hyponatraemia (in more serious cases with convulsions) on administration without restricting fluid intake, nasal congestion, nausea, stomach pain, vomiting,

Specific side effects

notKnown: rhinitis,

Hyponatraemic convulsions

The risk of hyponatraemic convulsions can be minimised by keeping to the recommended starting doses and by avoiding concomitant use of drugs which increase secretion of vasopressin (e.g. tricyclic antidepressants).

Directions for administration

DDVAP and Desmotabs tablets may be crushed.

DDAVP intranasal solution may be diluted with Sodium Chloride 0.9% to a concentration of 10 micrograms/mL.

In children

Higher doses of DDAVP by intravenous infusion, used in mild to moderate haemophilia and von Willebrand’s disease, may be diluted with 30–50 mL Sodium Chloride 0.9% intravenous infusion.

DDAVP injection may be administered orally.

In children

For intravenous infusion (Octim ), dilute with 50 mL of Sodium Chloride 0.9% and give over 20 minutes.

With intravenous use in adults

For intravenous infusion (DDVAP , Octim ), give intermittently in Sodium chloride 0.9%; dilute with 50 mL and give over 20 minutes.

Desmopressin oral lyophilisates are for sublingual administration.

Advice for patients and carers

Hyponatraemic convulsions

Patients being treated for primary nocturnal enuresis should be warned to avoid fluid overload (including during swimming) and to stop taking desmopressin during an episode of vomiting or diarrhoea (until fluid balance normal).

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Desmopressin for bedwetting

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/desmopressin-bedwetting-0

Cautions regarding administration

  • Asthma
  • avoid fluid overload
  • cardiovascular disease (not indicated for nocturnal enuresis or noctuira)
  • conditions which might be aggravated by water retention
  • cystic fibrosis
  • : elderly (avoid for nocturnal enuresis and nocturia in those over 65 years) in adults
  • epilepsy
  • heart failure
  • hypertension (not indicated for nocturnal enuresis or noctuira)
  • migraine
  • nocturia—limit fluid intake to minimum from 1 hour before dose until 8 hours afterwards
  • nocturnal enuresis—limit fluid intake to minimum from 1 hour before dose until 8 hours afterwards
  • With intranasal use: should not be given intranasally for nocturnal enuresis due to an increased incidence of side-effects

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

In nocturia, periodic blood pressure and weight checks are needed to monitor for fluid overload.

Unlicensed use

In children

Consult product literature for individual preparations.

Not licensed for assessment of antidiuretic hormone secretion.

Oral use of DDAVP intravenous injection is not licensed.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Oral, intranasal, intravenous, subcutaneous and intramuscular doses are expressed as desmopressin acetate; sublingual doses are expressed as desmopressin base.

Children requiring an intranasal dose of less than 10 micrograms should be given DDAVP intranasal solution.

Prepared medicinal forms of DESMOPRESSIN

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: oral suspension, spray, oral solution, capsule, nasal drops,
Tablet
Oral solution
Oral lyophilisate
Solution for injection
Spray
Nasal drops
